intro: Cacalia krameri, commonly known as the desert bluebell, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which is characterized by its composite flower heads composed of many small florets. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Its blue to violet flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Cacalia krameri is often found in desert scrub and chaparral habitats, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local wildlife.
